questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding mosquitoes?

options.A: It is the definitive host in malaria
options.B: Mansonia is a vector for Malayan filariasis
options.C: Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
options.D: All mosquitoes can travel only for 100 metres

questions.question: Which of the following species of mosquitoes breed in dirty water and water bodiescontaining aquatic vegetation respectively?
questions.explanation: Culex species of mosquitoes breed mostly in dirty and polluted water. Mansonia species ofmosquitoes breed in water bodies containing aquatic vegetation.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about larva of mosquitoes?

options.B: Culex larva lies in water with head faced downwards
options.C: Anopheles larva lies parallel to the undersurface of water

questions.explanation: Anopheles larva has no siphon tube as shown in the image below.The image given below shows Culex larva having a siphon tube.

questions.question: Identify the species of mosquito shown in the image below.623
questions.explanation: 632The given image is of an Aedes mosquito.They can be identified with the stripes on the legs and body. They are also called tiger mosquitoesbecause of their stripes.

questions.question: A 25-year-old lady from a tribal area presented with fever, chills, vomiting, and abdominalpain for 4 days. The peripheral smear of the patient is given below. Which of the following istrue about the mosquito which transmits this disease?

options.D: Keeps its body horizontal while feeding

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and peripheral smear showing ring form/ early trophozoites inerythrocytes are suggestive of Plasmodium falciparum malaria. It is transmitted by Anophelesmosquitoes. They have spotted wings.They breed in clean water. Their larva has no siphon tube and lies parallel to the undersurface ofwater. They tend to sit with their heads low and their rare ends raised high, especially whenfeeding.

questions.question: A patient presented with fever, headache, and retro-orbital pain for 3 days. He tested positivefor the NS1 antigen. Which of the following mosquitoes transmits the disease he's sufferingfrom?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the positive NS1 antigen test is suggestive of dengue fever.It is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito, which is also called as tiger mosquito.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by Aedes mosquito?
questions.explanation: Japanese encephalitis and West Nile fever are transmitted by Culex mosquitoes.Chikungunya, yellow fever, and rift valley fever are transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.

questions.question: A banker who is scheduled to travel to Congo is advised to take the yellow fever vaccine. Whatis the flight range of the mosquito which transmits this disease?
questions.explanation: Yellow fever is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito. Its flight range is 100 metres.

questions.question: 625A patient with fever and mucosal bleeding is diagnosed with dengue fever. Which of thefollowing is false about the mosquito which transmits this disease?

options.B: Development of larva from egg does not require water
options.D: It has a striped body pattern

questions.explanation: Dengue fever is transmitted by the Aedes mosquito. The conversion from the egg stage to thelarval stage of this mosquito requires water.Eggs of any mosquito species do not survive without water. But the eggs of Aedes mosquitoes liedormant in dry conditions for up to about nine months. They can hatch if exposed to favourableconditions such as water and food.633

questions.question: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with complaints of fever and headache for 5 days.Serological examination shows the presence of IgM antibodies to the JE virus. Which of thefollowing mosquitoes transmits this disease?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Japanese encephalitis. It is transmitted by Culexmosquitoes like Culex tritaeniorhynchus

questions.question: Match the following diseases and the mosquitoes which transmit them.

options.A: 1 - c, ll - a, lll - d, iV - b
options.B: 1 - a, ll - b, lll - c,IV - d
options.C: 1 b, llc, lll - d, IV - a--
options.D: 1 d, lla, lll - b, IV - c--

questions.explanation: The correctly matched diseases with the mosquitoes which transmit them are:DiseaseMosquitoYellow feverAedesBancroftian filariasisMalariaCulexAnophelesMalayan filariasisMansonia

questions.question: Which of the following is true about pathogenic mosquitoes?
questions.explanation: Aedes and Anopheles lay eggs singly.Culex lays eggs in rafts and Mansonia lays eggs in star-shaped clusters.Anopheles has spotted wings while the other pathogenic species have unspotted wings.Aedes transmits yellow fever, dengue and chikungunya. Culex is the main vector for JE andfilariasis.

questions.question: You are posted in a PHC in a coastal region as a part of your rural postings. Which of thefollowing Anopheles species is most commonly found here?
questions.explanation: Anopheles stephensi and Anopheles sundaicus are found in coastal regions.Anopheles stephensi is also the main vector of malaria in urban regions. Anopheles culicifaciesand Anopheles philippinensis are found in the plains. Anopheles fluviatilis and Anophelesminimus are found in foot-hill regions.

questions.question: Which of the following species of Anopheles mosquitoes transmits urban malaria?
questions.explanation: Urban malaria is transmitted by Anopheles stephensi.634

questions.question: What is the distance around an airport or seaport that has to be kept free of all mosquitoes?
questions.explanation: The distance around an airport or seaport that has to be kept free of all mosquitoes is 400 metres.This helps in limiting the spread of vector-borne diseases to new geographic regions.

questions.question: Identify the following vector.627
questions.explanation: The given image is of a housefly, whose scientific name is Musca domestica.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a method of disease transmission by houseflies?
questions.explanation: Houseflies do not transmit diseases by biting. They transmit diseases by mechanical transmissionby their legs or feet, vomit drop, and defecation.They transmit a variety of diseases like:• Typhoid• Polio•• Dysentery• Amoebiasis•• Anthrax• Yaws

questions.question: Which disease is transmitted by the following vector that is found in cracks and crevices ofwalls in the day time?628
questions.explanation: The given image is of a sandfly. It transmits visceral leishmaniasis.Note: Sandfly acts as a vector for the following diseases:• Kala-azar•Oriental sore•Sandfly fever•Oroya feverJapanese encephalitis is transmitted by the Culex mosquito. Dengue is transmitted bythe Aedes mosquito.Trypanosomiasis is transmitted by the tsetse fly.

questions.question: Sandfly does not transmit:
questions.explanation: 635Trench fever is not transmitted by sandflies. It is transmitted by lice and caused by Bartonellaquintana.

questions.question: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by the vector shown in the image given below?629
questions.explanation: The vector shown in the image is a tsetse fly. It transmits African sleeping sickness (Africanhuman trypanosomiasis).Tsetse flies belong to the genus Glossina. They have not demonstrated insecticideresistance. Methods of tsetse fly control include spraying of DDT, clearing of vegetation,destruction of wild game and genetic control.

questions.question: A patient presents with blurring of vision and a painless swelling over his left elbow whichhas gradually been increasing in size over the past 1 year. On examination, he is noted to havepatchy depigmentation on his legs. Which of the following vectors transmits the disease he'ssuffering from?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of onchocerciasis, also known as river blindness. It istransmitted by blackfly.The usual presentation of onchocerciasis is the formation of a subcutaneous nodule oronchocercoma. It is a firm non-tender nodule arising from bony sites like the scalp, elbow, ribs,and iliac crest. It is associated with pruritus and rashes. Patients also present with patchydepigmentation on the legs called leopard skin.The presence of microfilaria in the eye causes photophobia and gradual loss of vision. The mostsevere manifestations are sclerosing keratitis and chorioretinitis which can lead to blindness.Blackfly is also called Simulium. It has a flight range of almost 100 miles, making control of adultflies difficult. Abate is widely used as a larvicidal insecticide. The image given below shows ablackfly.636

questions.question: Spot the wrongly matched arthropod and disease.
questions.explanation: Blackflies (Simulium) are the vector for onchocerciasis and not Chaga's disease.An arthropod or an invertebrate that transmits infection is called a vector. It transmits infectionby:•• Inoculation into or through the skin or mucous membrane•Biting•Deposit of infective materials on skin or food or other objectsNote: Chagas disease is transmitted by the reduviid bugs or kissing bugs or triatomines.637
